title: Golang Data Types - Overview
content:
### Golang supports several built-in data types:
- **Basic types**: `int`, `float64`, `string`, `bool`
- **Composite types**: `array`, `slice`, `map`, `struct`
- **Reference types**: `pointer`, `interface`, `channel`, `function`

Each type is designed to optimize memory usage and performance.

title: Integer Data Type - Example
content:
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    var age int = 25
    var smallNumber int8 = 127
    fmt.Println("Age:", age)
    fmt.Println("Small Number:", smallNumber)
}

title: Floating-Point Data Type - Example
content:
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    var price float64 = 99.99
    var temperature float32 = 36.6
    fmt.Println("Price:", price)
    fmt.Println("Temperature:", temperature)
}

title: String Data Type - Example
content:
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    var name string = "John Doe"
    var greeting = "Hello, " + name
    fmt.Println(greeting)
}

title: Boolean Data Type - Example
content:
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    var isActive bool = true
    var hasAccess bool = false
    fmt.Println("Is Active:", isActive)
    fmt.Println("Has Access:", hasAccess)
}

Pointer Data Type - Example
content:
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    var num int = 10
    var ptr *int = &num
    fmt.Println("Number:", num)
    fmt.Println("Pointer Address:", ptr)
    fmt.Println("Pointer Value:", *ptr)
}

Channel Data Type - Example
content:

import "fmt"

func main() {
    ch := make(chan int)
    go func() { ch <- 5 }()
    fmt.Println("Received:", <-ch)
}
